bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to W. Byam, June 7, 1919

div1.p: Carter writes that he will change his map to reflect the distribution of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to W. Byam, June 7, 1919
div1.opener:
Miss,
Yellow Fever
Oxford Press.
/LC
June 7, 1919.
Major W. Byam, R. A. M. C.,
12 Heath Mansions,
Hampstead. N. W. 3. London, England.
Dear Major Byam:
div1.p:
The Wellcome map cannot possibly be intended to show the present
distribution of yellow fever, or even the places at which it has
been contracted. It is doubtless intended to give the areas at
which cases have developed--certainly none was ever contracted in
San Francisco, although I myself treated cases there (1885) con-
tracted on vessels en route from Mazatlan. To consider San Fran-
cisco: Nova Scotia and English ports in the same yellow fever group
as Guayaquil and Bahia seems to me unreasonable.

I will then, color black where I believe it to at present exist,
putting a question mark where I am doubtful and red its area of pre-
vious endemicity. This is for the Americas only. I know its his-
tory in Africa very well, but cannot mark its present prevalence.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Enclosures.
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
U. S. Marine Hospital,
Baltimore, Md. U. S. A.
